Award.AwardTitle: Coherent Dynamics of Spins Placed in Quantized Electromagnetic Fields and Studied Using Superconducting Device
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
The present proposal is focusing on implementing techniques closely related to quantum optics in solid-state systems containing diluted, highly coherent spins. The control of dynamics of spins in solid-state materials has direct implications at both fundamental and applied levels. Research topics, in particular quantum computing, rely heavily on both complex control techniques and long spin coherence times to achieve intricate and robust information control. One aspect of this proposal is to identify new supramolecular structures with long spin coherence times. A natural way of driving spin orientation is by using electromagnetic fields (photons) and it can be done either as a classical rotation or by entanglement with the field itself. The studies are to be performed at very low temperatures, using on-chip, superconducting devices (planar cavities and micro-squids). The present program will train undergraduate and graduate students, sustain PI's involvement in the Research Experience for Undergraduates and Teachers programs, and in the development of scientific demonstrations at outreach events in the FSU and NHMFL campuses

****Non-Technical Abstract****
Modern technological applications are aiming closer and closer to a limit where quantum mechanics is the main theoretical tool. Often, electronic chips and small components are involved in such applications. At the same time, an impressive amount of research has been done in the case of atoms in dilute gases, since such systems are governed purely by Quantum Mechanics. Here, we propose to implement techniques of quantum optics into the field of solid-state physics, to develop new experimental tools. Also, we will search for new supramolecular materials capable of sustaining for long times quantum information, for on-chip applications like Quantum Computing. The studies are to be performed at very low temperatures, using on-chip, superconducting devices (planar cavities and micro-squids). This research is intrinsically connected to the act of teaching: if we teach our students well, we will have top scientists in the future. The present program will train undergraduate and graduate students, sustain PI's involvement in the Research Experience for Undergraduates and Teachers programs, and in the development of scientific demonstrations at outreach events in the FSU and NHMFL campuses. Moreover, through association with the NHMFL, a broad condensed matter community (users, visitors, and students) will interact closely with the proposed research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this no-cost extension, the award provided support for one graduate student who graduated and moved to a postdoc position at Berkeley. The research project of one minority student in the APS Bridge program (Aidan Zabalo) was impacted by the award, by providing the infrastructure required for his measurements. Those measurements will make the object of a Master of Science (MSc) thesis and of one publication. The graduate student also provided instrumental help in two outreach activities done by the PI: a public lecture at the City of Tallahassee Public Library on Spin Resonance in the Quantum Regime and during the Saturday Morning Physics program in the Physics Department at FSU. Another PhD minority student (Giovanni Franco-Rivera) started to work in PI's group and he is currently in the training period, using the infrastructure acquired during the lifetime of this award and a previous NSF CAREER award.

One manuscript has been published in Scientific Reports (1) and two other ones are submitted to Phys Rev Letter (2) and Nature Materials (3). We expected in the near future to submit two more papers, one as a result of the MSc mentioned above and another one dealing with spin coherent phenomena in multi-level quantum systems.

In the current grant period, the experimental work has been focused on characterizing and improving the design of on-chip superconducting cavities, which are accommodating small amounts of magnetic sample (<1mm). Important features linked to dissipation in such systems has been noticed. In parallel, another project is studying the possibility of using the quantized nature of a DC SQUID to perform spin measurements in the so-called “resonant activation” regime. A SQUID can be represented by a washboard potential and such confinement provides a quantization of its energy levels which depends on chip properties (such as shunt capacitance) and the electrical current biasing the device. Preliminary measurements performed in our lab are showing well-defined resonances in the tens of GHz range which can be used as sensitive indicators of the size of the SQUID potential barrier. This barrier depends on the flux penetrating the SQUID and thus on the magnetic signal generated by quantum spins located on the same chip, in the vicinity of the SQUID and of a broadband waveguide. These preliminary results are a solid basis for future exploration of this principle of measurement.

(1) J. Hu, J.Y. Liu, D. Graf, S.M.A Radmanesh, D.J. Adams, A. Chuang, Y. Wang, I. Chiorescu, J. Wei, L. Spinu, Z.Q. Mao, Scientific Reports 6, 18674 (2016).

(2) M. Martens, J. van Tol, N.S. Dalal, S. Bertaina, I. Chiorescu, “Spin-Orbit Coupling Fluctuations as a Mechanism of Spin Decoherence”, submitted

(3) J.Y. Liu, J. Hu, Q. Zhang, D. Graf, H.B. Cao, S.M.A. Radmanesh, D.J. Adams, Y.L. Zhu, G.F. Cheng, X. Liu, W. A. Phelan, J. Wei, D. A. Tennant, J. F. DiTusa, I. Chiorescu, L. Spinu, Z.Q. Mao, submitted.
